title: Operating Systems - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Computer Science - Module 1: Lesson 4

questions.question: What is an Operating System?
options: Collection of programs that manages hardware resources
System service provider to the application programs
Link to interface the hardware and application programs
questions.explanation: An Operating System performs all three functions: it manages hardware resources, provides services to application programs, and acts as an interface between hardware and application programs.

questions.question: What is a process in operating system terminology?
options: Program in high-level language kept on disk
questions.explanation: A process is a program that is in an execution state. For example, MS-Word being run by a user on a personal computer is a process.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of an operating system?
questions.explanation: Compiling programs is the job of a compiler, not the operating system. The OS manages processes, memory, files, disks, and I/O devices.

questions.question: What does Process Management in an OS involve?
options: Creation, deletion, and scheduling of processes
questions.explanation: The operating system is responsible for creation, deletion, and scheduling of various processes that are being executed at any point of time.

questions.question: What does Memory Management in OS track?
options: Every memory location, whether assigned or free
questions.explanation: The OS keeps track of every memory location, that is either assigned to some process or is free. It also checks how much memory should be assigned to each process.

questions.question: What is required for OS to interact with hardware devices?
questions.explanation: The operating system requires device driver software to interact with a particular hardware device and perform I/O operations.

questions.question: What is a file in operating system terminology?
options: A sequence of bits, bytes, lines or records
questions.explanation: In general, a file is a sequence of bits, bytes, lines or records. It can contain programs, data, text, images, or any other type of information.

questions.question: Which user interface allows users to interact by typing commands?
questions.explanation: A Text User Interface (TUI) or Command Line Interface (CLI) allows users to interact with an operating system by typing commands in a terminal or console window.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a CLI-based operating system?
questions.explanation: DOS (Disk Operating System) and UNIX are examples of command line based operating systems where users type commands to perform tasks.

questions.question: What does GUI stand for?
questions.explanation: GUI stands for Graphical User Interface. It uses graphics, along with keyboard and mouse, to provide an easy-to-use interface.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a feature of GUI?
questions.explanation: GUI eliminates the need to memorize commands. It provides visual elements like menus, icons, buttons, and scrollbars for easy interaction.

questions.question: Which operating system is designed by Microsoft?
questions.explanation: Windows is an operating system designed by Microsoft. It is the most popular OS for home PCs.

questions.question: What was the most recent version of Windows mentioned in the text (as of the content)?
questions.explanation: Windows 10, released in 2015, is mentioned as the most recent version in the text, followed by Windows 8 (2012), Windows 7 (2009), and Windows Vista (2007).

questions.question: What does 'open source' mean in the context of operating systems?
options: The OS is free to download only
The source code is freely available for modification
The OS has an open interface
questions.explanation: Open source refers to program code which is freely available and its source code is available to developers or users for modification.

questions.question: Which operating system is an example of open source?
questions.explanation: Linux is an open-source operating system. Its source code is freely available and can be modified by developers and users.

questions.question: What are the three main components of Linux operating system?
questions.explanation: Linux has three main components: Kernel (core part), System library (special functions to access Kernel features), and System utility (for specialized tasks).

questions.question: What are the two GUIs typically provided by Linux?
questions.explanation: Linux typically provides two GUIs: KDE and Gnome. Different Linux distributions may offer these or other desktop environments.

questions.question: Which of the following is a Linux distribution?
questions.explanation: Ubuntu is a Linux distribution. Other distributions mentioned include Red Hat, SuSE, and Xandros.

questions.question: When was UNIX operating system developed?
questions.explanation: UNIX is an operating system developed in the 1960s. It is a stable, multi-user, multi-tasking system.

questions.question: Which are popular versions of UNIX?
questions.explanation: The most popular versions of UNIX are Sun Solaris and MacOS X, as mentioned in the text.

questions.question: What type of machines can UNIX be installed on?
questions.explanation: UNIX is a flexible operating system that can be installed on many different types of machines including mainframe computers, supercomputers, and microcomputers.

questions.question: Which operating system runs on Apple iPhone?
questions.explanation: Apple iOS is a multi-touch, multi-tasking operating system that runs on Apple iPhone, iPad, and iPod.

questions.question: Which feature of iOS allows users to enlarge images by touching the screen?
questions.explanation: iOS is a multi-touch operating system that gives response on user's touch, allowing them to tap to open programs or swipe fingers to change pages, and enlarge images.

questions.question: What is the app store for iOS called?
questions.explanation: iOS devices can download millions of apps from the App Store on any Apple device running iOS.

questions.question: Which company owns the Android operating system?
questions.explanation: Android is an open source mobile operating system owned by Google.

questions.question: What is a key characteristic of Android as an operating system?
options: It only works on Google phones
questions.explanation: Android is open source, meaning its source code is available and can be viewed, altered, and shared. This makes it fully customizable.

questions.question: When was Windows Phone platform released?
questions.explanation: Microsoft released its Windows platform for mobile phones in late 2010.

questions.question: What is the distinctive feature of Windows Phone interface?
questions.explanation: Windows phone is recognizable from its tile-based interface with square/rectangular shaped selectable icons that can be customized.

questions.question: What are 'hubs' in Windows Phone?
options: Aggregator feature that groups similar content together
questions.explanation: Hubs are an aggregator feature in Windows Phone that automatically groups content like photos, music from various applications together in one place.

questions.question: What is multiprogramming?
options: Running one program at a time
Ability to execute more than one program on a single processor
questions.explanation: Multiprogramming is the ability of an operating system to execute more than one program on a single processor machine with multiple programs residing in main memory.

questions.question: What is multitasking?
options: Ability to execute more than one task simultaneously on a single processor
questions.explanation: Multitasking is the ability of an OS to execute more than one task simultaneously on a single processor. The CPU switches between tasks so quickly it appears simultaneous.

questions.question: What is a multiuser operating system?
options: OS that allows one user with multiple accounts
OS that allows multiple users on different computers to access a single system
questions.explanation: A multiuser operating system allows multiple users on different computers or terminals to access a single system with one OS on it.

questions.question: In process scheduling, why does each process get limited CPU time?
options: To maximize CPU utilization and allow multiple processes to run
questions.explanation: Each process is allowed limited CPU time (fraction of a second) to maximize CPU utilization and allow multiple processes to run through quick CPU switching.

questions.question: Why does OS fragment large files into smaller pieces?
options: To save space on the disk
Because large files may not be stored in contiguous locations
questions.explanation: A large file may or may not be stored in a contiguous location on a physical disk drive. If the file is large, it is fragmented into smaller pieces, and the OS tracks each piece's location.

questions.question: Which OS follows hierarchical structure to store files and folders?
questions.explanation: Operating systems like DOS, Windows, Macintosh and Unix follow the hierarchical structure to store files and folders.

questions.question: What is the main difference between GUI and CLI in terms of ease of use?
options: CLI is easier for new users
GUI is easier as it uses icons and menus
questions.explanation: GUI is very easy to interact with the computer using icons, menus, and buttons. New users find CLI difficult as it requires memorization of commands.

questions.question: Which interface requires fewer system resources?
questions.explanation: Very few computer resources are needed when CLI is running. GUI requires a lot of system resources as drivers for video, mouse and other devices need to be loaded.

questions.question: Which provides more control over the operating system and file system?
questions.explanation: Users using CLI get much more control over the operating system and the file system. Advanced level tasks can be performed only through commands.

questions.question: What comes with iOS for internet access?
questions.explanation: Apple iOS comes with the Safari web browser for internet access, iTunes for music, and Mail app for emails.

questions.question: What does OS do with peripheral devices?
questions.explanation: The operating system controls peripheral devices such as disk drives and printers, managing input/output operations.

questions.question: What is the role of OS in resource allocation?
options: It controls allocation of resources like memory, processors, devices
questions.explanation: An operating system controls the allocation of resources like memory, processors, devices, and information among various programs.

questions.question: Which web browser comes with Windows Phone?
questions.explanation: Windows OS comes with Internet Explorer for web access and Microsoft Exchange for secure corporate emails access.

questions.question: What are apps in smartphone context?
options: Software programs developed for smartphones for specific functions
questions.explanation: Apps (applications) are software programs developed for smartphones that can perform specific functions, available through app stores.

questions.question: Which OS has better built-in security features compared to Windows?
questions.explanation: UNIX has better built-in security and permissions features than Windows.

questions.question: What ensures that different programs and users don't interfere with each other?
questions.explanation: The operating system makes sure that different programs and multi-users do not interfere with each other through proper resource management and process control.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about Windows OS?
options: It is GUI-based and supports multitasking
questions.explanation: Windows is a GUI-based operating system that supports multiprogramming and multitasking, allowing several programs to be opened at the same time.

questions.question: Which smartphone OS has millions of mostly free apps?
questions.explanation: The Android market has millions of apps, most of which are totally free, due to its open source nature and fewer licensing restrictions.

questions.question: What is the core part of Linux responsible for major activities?
questions.explanation: The Kernel is the core part of Linux and is responsible for major activities of the operating system.
